primary.request: speak to a supervisor about billing
primary.context: Caller received a billing statement with an unfamiliar name (Sonia Diaz) and is legally blind.
primary.detail: The agent attempted to transfer the caller to concierge, but after a 20-minute hold, the system reported no agents were available and the call ended.

steps: Caller requested a supervisor for a billing issue.
Agent offered a transfer with a 20-minute wait warning; caller accepted.
After 20 minutes of hold music, the AI re-engaged stating no one was available.
Caller attempted to provide account details to the AI instead.
AI failed to verify the account because the name on the statement (Sonia Diaz) did not match the caller (Richard).
AI attempted a second transfer, which also resulted in a 'no agents available' message.

failure.detail: Agent persisted in a rigid verification flow for a caller who explicitly stated they were calling about an unfamiliar name on a bill, rather than escalating immediately.

clarifications.note: Offering choice of phone or contract ID
Insisting on name verification despite mismatch explanation

corrections.note: Caller clarifies he is not the contract holder

actions.detail: First transfer attempt timed out after 20 minutes
Looked up record via phone number
Name mismatch: Richard vs Sonia Diaz
Second transfer failed due to no agents available

insights.summary: The caller wanted to discuss a billing error involving an unfamiliar name. After a 20-minute failed transfer, the AI attempted to verify the account but could not proceed due to the name mismatch, eventually ending the call when the second transfer also failed.
insights.verbatim: It has a name I never heard of. Sonia Diaz. D I a z.
insights.coaching: When a caller explicitly states they are calling about a bill with an unfamiliar name, the agent should recognize this as a potential billing error or fraud inquiry and escalate to a human rather than forcing a standard verification loop that is guaranteed to fail.
